awd_titl_txt: HDR DSC: Collaborative Research: The Data Science WAV: Experiential Learning with Local Community Organizations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project simultaneously addresses two problems: 1) the inability of community-based and non-profit organizations to tackle data science problems; and 2) the lack of real world experience gained by students studying data science. The increased availability of data, combined with increased computing power at lower costs, has brought to the desktop tremendous analytical and problem solving capabilities. Yet many organizations are not able to take advantage of these developments because they often lack appropriate staffing to wrestle with complex data science problems. Meanwhile, as students increasingly gravitate toward data science programs, much of their course-based problem solving experience focuses on clean problems with simple data sets. This leaves them unprepared for the reality of the data science applications they will face in professional settings. This project addresses both issues by deploying teams of data science students to assist local organizations, thereby increasing the long-term capacity of the data science workforce.

This is a multifaceted project that will provide immediate impact to local organizations and long-term benefit for students through valuable hands-on data science experience. There are two major components of the proposed project. First, Data Science WAV teams of four specially-trained undergraduate students will be deployed to community-based organizations to Wrangle, Analyze, and Visualize their data. Second, this project will offer summer faculty development workshops designed to help new instructors, especially those at community colleges, teach data science at their institutions. Curricular innovations that bring experiential data science learning into the curriculum will lead to sustained impact at the partnering academic institutions and in the larger Pioneer Valley region. This proposal is diverse across both institutions and student populations. It comprises one major research university (The University of Massachusetts, Amherst), four liberal arts colleges (Amherst, Hampshire, Mount Holyoke, and Smith), and three local community colleges (Greenfield, Holyoke, and Springfield Technical). The inclusion of two women's colleges (Smith and Mount Holyoke) and two Hispanic-serving institutions (Holyoke and Springfield Technical) will help ensure that a diverse student population is engaged in the project. 

NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution Data Science Corps program focuses on building capacity for harnessing the data revolution at the local, state, national, and international levels to help unleash the power of data in the service of science and society. Projects in this program are being jointly funded by the NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea; the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, Division of Information and Intelligent Systems; the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education; the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Division of Mathematical Sciences; and the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences, Office of Multidisciplinary Activities and Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
HDR DSC: Collaborative Research: The Data Science WAV: Experiential Learning with Local Community Organizations

Data science is a new STEM field that is both lucrative and could attract and excite more students to STEM. It could also serve as an alternative for statistics for a lot of our students and it will empower the students to think critically. Data science could be used to study issues of social justice, climate change, global health and other issues that affect our students' lives to better help them understand the current digital world we live in.  The study of data would give a student an introduction to computational thinking.  Data science is a relatively new field that would put HCC at the forefront of CC work in this area. 

The NSF-funded Data Science Corps - Wrangle, Analyze, Visualize project (NSF# 1922982) was focused on expanding the data science workforce by increasing the size and diversity of the pool of skilled data science workers. One major component of that project (which we work on at Holyoke Community College) was to  build data science pathways for students from community colleges to public four-year colleges. Our goal was to establish pathways and agreements which would allow students at those community colleges to transfer to four year schools in the area and be in good standing towards a bachelor’s degree in data science. 

By far the largest obstacle had been the absence of an introductory data science course at community colleges, and second, the absence of a two-year or certificate degree in data science.  If students could not learn about data science until their third year of college,  they would already be behind their peers who attended a 4 year institution. In addition, community college faculty at HCC also needed to learn the topic themselves in order to develop such a course and such a program.Despite the impacts of the pandemic, this project has successfully completed many of the program objectives.

Intellectual Merit:

 Holyoke Community College Faculty participated in professional development workshops in 2021 and 2022 aimed at teaching them introductory R/R-studio and data science skills. These workshops were designed and offered by the DSC-WAV PIs. 

  • An Introductory Data Science course was designed and passed through governance so that this new course now counts as a mathematics college level course. The Introductory Data Science course was successfully offered twice at Holyoke Community College during the duration of the project.
  • In addition, agreements with local four year institutions (UMass Amherst, Westfield State, Smith College) to accept the introductory data science course were created.  Simultaneously, a data science network of faculty from HCC and transfer institutions (Westfield State University, Smith College) has been working on drafting a two-year data science program that will be launched in the near future.
  • A second Data Science course focused on visualization is under consideration.
  • Finally, the HCC data science faculty trained in offered a home grown professional development three day workshop to introduce other community college faculty to  teaching statistics with R and introductory Data Science  to other community college faculty during the summer of 2023.

Broader Impact:

A program with a clearly articulated pathway to bachelor’s level programs has the potential to  boost community college enrollment  and add a field of study for students that leads to a career with significantly above average earning potential. In addition, these data science pathways will be some of the  in Massachusetts, and will provide the model for other community colleges in Massachusetts, or even throughout New England. Since approximately 50% of students who complete Bachelor’s Degree programs begin their education at community colleges, the work done in this project, and since students at community colleges also tend to be those who have been traditionally marginalized, the DSC WAV initiative has an equity-centered broader impact, not only as far as access, but also in terms of the impact of this growing field: To the extent that we can diversify the demographic makeup of the data science community (currently predominantly white and male), we can enrich and inform a wider range of data narratives and gain further insight to inform policy and decision-making. Historically excluded populations -- like those who attend our community colleges -- who gain exposure to the data science field will have an opportunity to reap the benefits of data science as a career and to bring their skills to bear on issues that affect them personally.

Developing a diverse population of data scientists provides the next generation of scholars with compelling, relevant role models and opens the field to groups underrepresented in data science communities.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Ileana Vasu

 By far the largest obstacle had been the absence of an introductory data science course at community colleges, and second, the absence of a two-year or certificate degree in data science. An Introductory Data Science course was designed and passed through governance so that this new course now counts as a mathematics college level course. The Introductory Data Science course was successfully offered twice at Holyoke Community College during the duration of the project.
In addition, agreements with local four year institutions (UMass Amherst, Westfield State, Smith College) to accept the introductory data science course were created. Historically excluded populations -- like those who attend our community colleges -- who gain exposure to the data science field will have an opportunity to reap the benefits of data science as a career and to bring their skills to bear on issues that affect them personally. 


 Developing a diverse population of data scientists provides the next generation of scholars with compelling, relevant role models and opens the field to groups underrepresented in data science communities.
